texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This rather plain-looking species is of average body shape and eye size and the dorsal fin lacks both an anterior crest and notch in the membrane. Dorsal fin has 33–36 spines and 8–9 rays, these being about 1.5 times longer than the spines, thus raised into a slight posterior hump. The cirrus above the eye is the most unique identification feature and is a flat stalk with a fringe of fine, elongate filaments. Body colour is fairly uniform light pink or yellow brown with irregular mottling and indistinct vertical bars which extend onto the dorsal fin.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Has a restricted distribution only from Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
Rare and seldom photographed, but usually found subtidally on sandy substrata. Nothing else known about biology.
Unknown for this species, but other members of genus feed on a wide range of benthic invertebrates.

All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom. Details unknown for this species.
Fairly inconspicuous and rare species, but easily recognised by the unusual form of cirri above the eye.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 394).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 763).
